title: How to Choose the Perfect Candle Wax: A Beginner’s Guide
author: Admin
excerpt: With so many candle wax options available, how do you know which one is right for your DIY candle project? This guide breaks down the pros and cons of different wax types so you can create beautiful, fragrant candles every time.
content:
Types of Candle Wax:
1. Soy Wax
	● Pros: Natural, clean burn, excellent scent throw
	● Cons: Can frost (natural but some find it unappealing)
	● Best for: Container candles, beginners
2. Beeswax
	● Pros: Natural honey scent, long burn time
	● Cons: Expensive, harder to work with
	● Best for: Pillars, natural home decor
3. Paraffin Wax
	● Pros: Holds color/fragrance well, affordable
	● Cons: Petroleum-based, sooty burn
	● Best for: Detailed molded candles
4. Coconut Wax
	● Pros: Luxurious, excellent scent throw
	● Cons: Pricier, softer consistency
	● Best for: Luxury container candles
Pro Tip: For beginners, we recommend starting with soy wax - it's user-friendly and available in easy-to-melt flakes!

title: The Ultimate Guide to Choosing Yarn for Your Next Knitting or Crochet Project
author: Jane Doe
excerpt: Choosing the right yarn can make or break your knitting or crochet project. With so many fibers, weights, and textures available, it’s easy to feel overwhelmed. This guide will help you pick the perfect yarn every time.
content:
Understanding Yarn Fibers
Different fibers have unique properties that affect drape, warmth, and durability:
	● Wool: Warm, elastic, and great for winter wear. (Try merino for softness!)
	● Cotton: Breathable and sturdy, ideal for dishcloths and summer tops.
	● Acrylic: Budget-friendly, easy-care, and great for beginners.
	● Alpaca: Luxuriously soft and lightweight, perfect for scarves.
	● Bamboo: Silky and eco-friendly, excellent for drapey garments.
Texture & Special Yarns
	● Variegated/Self-Striping: Adds automatic color interest.
	● Chenille: Ultra-soft for plush toys and blankets.
	● Tweed/Marl: Adds subtle texture to classic designs.
Pro Tip: Always check the yarn label for recommended needle/hook size and care instructions!

title: Candle Making 101: Step-by-Step Tutorial for Beginners
author: Admin
excerpt: There’s something magical about lighting a candle you made yourself. Whether you want to create personalized gifts or a relaxing ambiance at home, candle making is an addictive (and surprisingly simple) hobby.
content:
Supplies You’ll Need
	● Wax: Soy (eco-friendly, clean burn) or paraffin (holds scent well).
	● Wicks: Pre-tabbed or spooled (size depends on container diameter).
	● Fragrance Oils: Use candle-safe scents (typically 6–10% of wax weight).
	● Containers: Mason jars, tins, or heat-resistant vessels.
	● Tools: Double boiler, thermometer, hobby pliers (for wick placement).
Step-by-Step Instructions:
1. Melt the Wax
	● Use a double boiler to melt wax flakes slowly (never microwave!). Heat to 185°F (85°C).
2. Add Fragrance & Color
	● Stir in fragrance oil at 170°F (77°C). For color, use dye chips or liquid dyes.
3. Prepare the Container
	● Secure the wick with a dab of hot glue or a wick sticker. Use pliers to center it.
4. Pour the Wax
	● Let the wax cool slightly (to 135°F/57°C) to prevent cracking. Pour slowly.
5. Let It Set
	● Allow 24 hours for the candle to harden. Trim the wick to ¼ inch before burning.
Troubleshooting Tips:
	● Sinkholes? Re-pour a thin layer of wax after the first sets.
	● Weak Scent? Increase fragrance oil (but don’t exceed 10%).
	● Tunneling? Burn the candle for at least 2 hours on first use.
